title: 1651-E
statement: E. Sum of Matchingstime limit per test4 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLet's denote the size of the maximum matching in a graph $$$G$$$ as $$$\\mathit{MM}(G)$$$.You are given a bipartite graph. The vertices of the first part are numbered from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$, the vertices of the second part are numbered from $$$n+1$$$ to $$$2n$$$.Each vertex's degree is $$$2$$$.For a tuple of four integers $$$(l, r, L, R)$$$, where $$$1 \\le l \\le r \\le n$$$ and $$$n+1 \\le L \\le R \\le 2n$$$, let's define $$$G'(l, r, L, R)$$$ as the graph which consists of all vertices of the given graph that are included in the segment $$$[l, r]$$$ or in the segment $$$[L, R]$$$, and all edges of the given graph such that each of their endpoints belongs to one of these segments. In other words, to obtain $$$G'(l, r, L, R)$$$ from the original graph, you have to remove all vertices $$$i$$$ such that $$$i \\notin [l, r]$$$ and $$$i \\notin [L, R]$$$, and all edges incident to these vertices.Calculate the sum of $$$\\mathit{MM}(G(l, r, L, R))$$$ over all tuples of integers $$$(l, r, L, R)$$$ having $$$1 \\le l \\le r \\le n$$$ and $$$n+1 \\le L \\le R \\le 2n$$$.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 1500$$$) — the number of vertices in each part.Then $$$2n$$$ lines follow, each denoting an edge of the graph. The $$$i$$$-th line contains two integers $$$x_i$$$ and $$$y_i$$$ ($$$1 \\le x_i \\le n$$$; $$$n + 1 \\le y_i \\le 2n$$$) — the endpoints of the $$$i$$$-th edge.There are no multiple edges in the given graph, and each vertex hasexactlytwo incident edges.OutputPrint one integer — the sum of $$$\\mathit{MM}(G(l, r, L, R))$$$ over all tuples of integers $$$(l, r, L, R)$$$ having $$$1 \\le l \\le r \\le n$$$ and $$$n+1 \\le L \\le R \\le 2n$$$.ExampleInput5 4 6 4 9 2 6 3 9 1 8 5 10 2 7 3 7 1 10 5 8Output314

processed.result:
You are given a bipartite graph with $n$ vertices in each part. The vertices are numbered from 1 to $n$ in the first part and from $n+1$ to $2n$ in the second part. Each vertex has a degree of 2.

For a tuple of four integers $(l, r, L, R)$, where $1 \le l \le r \le n$ and $n+1 \le L \le R \le 2n$, define $G(l, r, L, R)$ as the subgraph consisting of all vertices in the segments $[l, r]$ and $[L, R]$, and all edges connecting vertices within these segments.

Calculate the sum of the maximum matching sizes of all possible subgraphs $G(l, r, L, R)$. 

The maximum matching size of a graph is the maximum number of edges that can be selected from the graph such that no two edges share a common vertex. 



Let me know if you'd like me to elaborate on any part of the problem.

You are given a graph with two sets of vertices. Each vertex has exactly two connections to vertices in the other set.  You need to find the sum of the maximum number of connections possible within smaller subgraphs formed by selecting ranges of vertices from each set.
